articles.headline: Bulger Guilty in Gangland Crimes, Including Murder
articles.snippet: James (Whitey) Bulger, the mobster who terrorized South Boston in the 1970s and ’80s as leader of the Winter Hill Gang, faces a sentence of life in prison.
articles.abstract: James (Whitey) Bulger, the mobster who terrorized South Boston in the 1970s and ’80s as leader of the Winter Hill Gang, faces a sentence of life in prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — James (Whitey) Bulger, the mobster who terrorized South Boston in the 1970s and ‘80s, holding the city in his thrall even after he disappeared, was convicted Monday of a sweeping array of gangland crimes, including 11 murders. He faces the prospect of spending the rest of his life in prison.

articles.headline: New Laws and Rising Costs Create a Surge of Supersizing Hospitals
articles.snippet: After holding steady through much of the 2000s, deal-making has picked up in health care, raising concerns about the power of large hospital systems.
articles.abstract: After holding steady through much of the 2000s, deal-making has picked up in health care, raising concerns about the power of large hospital systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hospitals across the nation are being swept up in the biggest wave of mergers since the 1990s, a development that is creating giant hospital systems that could one day dominate American health care and drive up costs.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: An Odd Crown for Atlanta: Most Guns at the Airport
articles.snippet: Security agents at American airports have confiscated more than 800 guns so far in 2013, setting a pace that is likely to beat last year’s record of 1,556.
articles.abstract: Security agents at American airports have confiscated more than 800 guns so far in 2013, setting a pace that is likely to beat last year’s record of 1,556.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — For most fliers, the standard slap-your-forehead moment occurs after opening a suitcase upon arrival and discovering that they forgot to pack their prescription medicine, running shoes or perfect necktie.

articles.headline: In One Bundle of Mortgages, the Subprime Crisis Reverberates
articles.snippet: A Goldman Sachs bond with a complex name — GSAMP Trust 2007 NC1 — has wide-ranging impact, on the bankers who sold the deal, the struggling homeowners, and taxpayers who helped pick up the bill.
articles.abstract: A Goldman Sachs bond with a complex name — GSAMP Trust 2007 NC1 — has wide-ranging impact, on the bankers who sold the deal, the struggling homeowners, and taxpayers who helped pick up the bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: A subprime deal came back to haunt Fabrice Tourre, a former Goldman Sachs trader, when a federal jury in Manhattan found him liable for civil securities fraud.

articles.headline: Wall St. Debates Who Should Pay Legal Bills
articles.snippet: Legal troubles on Wall Street lead to a question: who pays the legal fees for the accused?
articles.abstract: Legal troubles on Wall Street lead to a question: who pays the legal fees for the accused?
articles.lead_paragraph: Who should foot the legal bill?

articles.headline: Arms Shipments Seen From Sudan to Syria Rebels
articles.snippet: Syrian rebels have found an unlikely source for arms in Sudan, whose government sold the weapons to Qatar, which arranged delivery through Turkey, Western officials and the rebels said.
articles.abstract: Syrian rebels have found an unlikely source for arms in Sudan, whose government sold the weapons to Qatar, which arranged delivery through Turkey, Western officials and the rebels said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Syrian rebels, frustrated by the West’s reluctance to provide arms, have found a supplier in an unlikely source: Sudan, a country that has been under international arms embargoes and maintains close ties with a stalwart backer of the Syrian government, Iran.
articles.byline: By C. J. Chivers and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: A Limit on Consumer Costs Is Delayed in Health Care Law
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has put off another provision — on deductibles and co-payments — until 2015.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has put off another provision — on deductibles and co-payments — until 2015.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In another setback for President Obama’s health care initiative, the administration has delayed until 2015 a significant consumer protection in the law that limits how much people may have to spend on their own health care.

articles.headline: Two Powerful Signals of a Major Shift on Crime
articles.snippet: A move to curb mandatory minimum sentences and a ruling that stop-and-frisk practices in New York were unconstitutional represented a swing away from the tough-on-crime policies of a generation ago.
articles.abstract: A move to curb mandatory minimum sentences and a ruling that stop-and-frisk practices in New York were unconstitutional represented a swing away from the tough-on-crime policies of a generation ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two decisions Monday, one by a federal judge in New York and the other by Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., were powerful signals that the pendulum has swung away from the tough-on-crime policies of a generation ago.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Erica Goode

articles.headline: U.S., Filing Suit, Moves to Block Airline Merger
articles.snippet: The Justice Department filed an antitrust lawsuit on Tuesday seeking to block the proposed merger of American Airlines and US Airways.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department filed an antitrust lawsuit on Tuesday seeking to block the proposed merger of American Airlines and US Airways.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:44 p.m. | After a decade of rapid consolidation in the nation’s airline industry, the Justice Department filed a lawsuit on Tuesday to block the proposed merger between American Airlines and US Airways, which would create the world’s largest airline.

articles.headline: A Wall St. Brawler’s Winning Qualities Also Play Out in Defeat
articles.snippet: William A. Ackman’s defeat at J.C. Penny may highlight not only the flaws of his approach but also the limits of what shareholder activists can achieve.
articles.abstract: William A. Ackman’s defeat at J.C. Penny may highlight not only the flaws of his approach but also the limits of what shareholder activists can achieve.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:27 p.m. |  The hedge fund titan William A. Ackman is not an investor known to make small bets. Yet one of his gambles, on turning around a dowdy department store chain, has blown up, leading him to make an embarrassing retreat.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Stephanie Clifford
